bestBHT.bht: The devil, knowing Jesus' power to dispossess him, threw the man down and convulsed him in a terrible manner. This violent act highlights the ongoing struggle between Jesus and the devil, as seen in similar events described in the Gospels. The devil aimed to cause as much harm as possible, demonstrating his desperation. However, this confrontation ultimately underscores Jesus' eventual victory over evil forces.

Marvin Vincent: Threw him down [ερρηξεν] . See on teareth, Mark 9:18. Tare [συνεσπαραξεν] . Only here in New Testament."
Convulse, which is the exact Latin equivalent, would, perhaps, be the nearest rendering. Sparagmov, a kindred noun, is the word for a cramp."
John Gill: the devil threw him down, and tare him; knowing who Jesus was, and that he was able to dispossess him
and having reason to believe he would, was resolved to do all the mischief he could
and therefore threw him to the ground, and convulsed him in a terrible manner at the same time

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse describes how the devil threw and convulsed the man, as if trying to cause as much harm as possible, because he knew Jesus was able to deliver him. This violent act emphasizes the power struggle between Jesus and the devil. This event is similar to other instances in the Gospels where Jesus predicts his death and resurrection, highlighting the ongoing conflict and Jesus' ultimate victory over evil.

The devil violently threw and convulsed the man, fully aware of Jesus' ability to deliver him. This malicious act demonstrates the intense power struggle between Jesus and the devil, emphasizing the magnitude of the conflict. Just as in other Gospel accounts where Jesus predicts his impending death and resurrection, this event serves as a reminder of the ongoing battle and ultimate triumph of Jesus over evil forces.
